author: @streaky8844
text: This works on the version of python 3.9.2:  import os  def closeFile():     try:          os.system('TASKKILL /F /IM notepad.exe')      except Exception as e: print(e)

author: @lassmicharztichbindurch5319
text: def openFile(file):     try:         os.startfile(file)     except Exception as e:         print(str(e))  def closeFile(file):     try:         os.system("TASKKILL /F /IM"+file)     except Exception as e:         print(str(e)) #this is working

text: Great video. But can you mention which version of Python you use?  Evidently your code was done in Python 2 and I can tell because Python 3 needs parentheses around the print object.  And it does not work for 3.  Here is what I used:    from os import *  def openFile():     try:         os.startfile('G:\Digital Learning Academy Home Laptop\Python Final Project-Astrology Signs\Background Hex Code for Astrological Signs.txt ')       except Exception as e:         print (str(e))   and I get this    RESTART: G:/Digital Learning Academy Home Laptop/Python at Home/How to Open and Close Progams.py  >>> openFile() name 'os' is not defined   Please help!

author: @jagfrediani
text: Hi Sentdex, great how simple and effective you explained it. I'd like to take it one step further, I'm sure you will help me. I need to open an executable, let it run and close the program after it finishes. I managed to do that using pywinauto and setting a timer. So, after X seconds, the program executed would close. However, it is far from efficient because some times it would take 20 seconds, some times it would take 200. I would like to remove that dead time. So, how can I make python know when the executable is finished so that it can kill the application? Thanks in advance (y)
